title: Friday, 13th May, 2016

Inmarsat PLC (ISAT:LSE): Last: 740.50, down 53.5 (-6.74%), High: 782.00, Low: 730.00, Volume: 1.85m

Oh. Dear

BE

Ma-hoosive profit warning overnight from Eutelsat

PM

BE

Eutelsat touches on themes in Inmarsat's recent warning, but turbocharging them.

11:14 am
BE

Namely, there are too many damn satellites up there and not enough customers.

BE

This is HTS, high throughput satellites

BE

Which are cheaper to get into space

11:16 am
BE

Creating an ideal environment for a hugely deflationary price war

BE

Because the costs are sunk upfront, before you get any customers, who you then recruit at any marginal rate

BE

(Though I know some feltcollaredsource readers disagree with this thesis, and I welcome their input.)

11:17 am
BE

So anyway ...........

BE

Eutelsat data services declined 12.6% organic

BE

Latin America the biggest problem, among many problems.

11:18 am
BE

"In recent weeks, trends until now impacting the EMEA region, notably pricing pressure, have begun to manifest themselves in other geographies."

BE

There's also a Ka-band contract cancellation on Eutelsat 3B, a weird drop in government business, and a frankly inexplicable dropoff of the TV side.

BE

Which is Eutelsat's core market. As in Hotbird Video over Europe.

11:20 am
BE

The stuff you can watch if you buy a card off a bloke in Shepherds Bush market.

BE

Barclays incoming.

PM

Hotbird Video? I dare not click

11:21 am
BE

It's not what you think. Though also it is, on some channels.

BE

Eutelsat: No more growth. Management is guiding to flat constant FX growth in FY16 and -1 to -3% in FY17, with EBITDA margins of 76% and 75%. This compares to previous guidance of +2% and +4-6%, and margins of 76.5% in both years. The No1 problem is that newly-launched data-focused satellites, focusing on Latin America, are filling much slower than hoped. They are experiencing tough pricing and competition amid oversupply, the arrival of data-focused HTS and weak economic conditions. Importantly ETL also indicates that some Video transponders are being returned by customers.

HTS: High levels of supply, lower barriers to entry. High Throughput Satellites are a new generation of satellites that can deliver much more capacity than traditional satellites (see A transition year) for the same capex/costs so it has a much lower unit cost (as much as 10x lower according to Eutelsat). Also because they operate on the largely unused Ka-Band frequency, this enables the entry of new players who have no incentive to protect prices from the traditional satellites. We estimate that around USD13bn will be invested between 2010-2017 in HTS adding around 2Tb of capacity to the industry.

Inmarsat: Many uncertainties, little reflected in the price. Last week ISAT posted Q1 2016 results below expectations and cut core FY 16e revenue guidance. The company highlighted tough trading conditions in its legacy business and also indicated that getting GX operational was taking longer than expected, delaying revenue generation. We view these results illustrate well the challenges the company is facing (volatile demand, ramp up of new product). We cut our short and mid term estimates after Q1 2016 results (we cut revenues by c. 1%/5%/3% for 2016/17/18 and cut EBITDA by c. 1%/8%/5%). We are 8% below the mid-point of revenue guidance for 2018e (ex Ligado) and -7% 2018e EBITDA consensus estimates. ISAT trades on P/E 2016e of 26x.

BE

Inmarsat's already guided towards being a 2018 company in a long and painful transition period

11:22 am
BE

So that 26 times 2016 is not terribly relevant.

BE

The Group sources the majority of its liquid chocolate, made to exclusive recipes, from a single supplier, Barry Callebaut. Whilst the supply relationship has been in place for over 10 years, not only is the supplier able to produce supplies at multiple locations, but there are alternate suppliers available. An event leading to the sudden or unforeseen loss of supply could materially adversely affect the Group’s ability to produce the required volume of finished goods for sales and, accordingly, its prospects, financial condition and its ability to develop its business.

BE

Which is fine.

BE

Barry Callebaut makes good chocolate. It's the world's biggest maker of the stuff after all.

ha, yes

11:31 am
PM

But that reduces the hurricane risk, surely

BE

Well, there is that.

BE

Saint Lucia
The Group produces some of its cocoa on its plantation in Saint Lucia, sources beans from other Saint Lucian growers and operates a hotel, spa and restaurant on the plantation. The Saint Lucian operations are important to the brand and also provide an understanding of cocoa growing. In FY15 Saint Lucia accounted for less than 2 per cent. of Group revenue and gross profits. The island is subject to the risk of hurricanes, which have historically occurred on 16 occasions in the last 166 years. The Rabot estate is located in an area of potential seismic and volcanic activity. The last eruption on Saint Lucia occurred in 1766, the University of West Indies reports that “this area is still potentially active and the island can therefore expect volcanic eruptions in the future.” There is a risk that weather events or geological activity could cause damage either to the business or the infrastructure on the island which might adversely impact tourist visitor numbers resulting in a reduction in revenue for a period of time. External events including crime or disease could reduce the number of tourists choosing to visit Saint Lucia which could reduce hotel revenues and profits.

BE

Here's Credit Suisse to talk is through it all.

BE

Organic revenue in line: A better revenue per case (+2.0% vs. consensus
+1.4%) offset weaker volume growth (0.1% vs. consensus 0.8%), to drive organic
revenue in-line with consensus. Underlying organic revenue grew by +3.5%,
adjusting for the impact of one fewer selling day (will reverse in Q4) setting the
company well on track to achieve their FY16 expectations. TP (1480p) and rating
(Neutral) unchanged.

BE

Volumes miss in Established: Volume miss was led by Established markets
(Switzerland, Greece and Ireland down mid single digits %). Elsewhere volumes
were much as we had expected. Uncertainty around Russia persists, but Russia
should sequentially improve in H2, while Nigeria should continue to benefit from
innovation (juices, new PET pack size), and hence, we maintain our expectations
for the region.

11:39 am
BE

Strong price momentum in Emerging, Developing is due to improve: The
beat in revenue per case was led by Emerging (Russia, Ukraine, Belarus), due to
price increases following significant currency depreciation in the region - the
6.5% price/mix in the region is the highest it has been over the last 3 years.
Despite deflationary pricing in Established and Developing, revenue per case
slightly improved, in part helped by better mix (stronger single-serve
contribution). We expect price/mix momentum to improve slightly for the FY from
plans to accelerate single serve pack sizes and capitalise on price increases in
the region
■ On balance, a good start to the year, though Q1 is a small quarter. The better
pricing is encouraging for margin (as is the recent improvement in FX), but Q2
and Q3 are the main quarters for profits.

BE

What happened to the idea of HBC buying Coca-Cola Beverages Africa, incidentally?

BE

I lost track of that theory.

Vedanta Resources PLC (VED:LSE): Last: 368.64, up 23.64 (+6.85%), High: 373.00, Low: 341.50, Volume: 271.08k
PM

11:55 am
BE

Paid a divi yesterday, but also convinced Cairn India to roll over $1.5bn of inter-company debt.

BE

Which was extremely generous of Cairn India.

BE

Theory is that the debt extension takes the pressure off Vedanta's interminable process to merge its subsidiaries.

11:56 am
BE

Or, at least, kicks that can further down the road.

BE

Here's Barclays.

BE

Vedanta is turning a corner of sorts. Its maturity profile now looks manageable, and
we expect net debt/EBITDA to decline in FY17 albeit due to EBITDA rising rather than
net debt declining. The company’s principal commodity exposures, zinc and oil (56%
of FY17 EBITDA), should offer some potential for upside. Some valuation metrics are
starting to look interesting too with EV/EBITDA at 6.2x and 4.5x in CY16-17 while
FCF/EV is 5% and 11%, respectively. That said, there is limited downside protection to
the equity should commodity prices fall, on our estimates. Our spot NPV and SOTP
both indicate negative equity values, in line with Vedanta’s negative book value just
reported for March-16. Hence, we remain UW for now.

11:57 am
BE

Refi remains a risk but now more manageable: Vedanta remains dependent on
bank/bond markets to continue its refinancing program. While it has been successful so
far, there are signs it is becoming trickier. The company has resorted to paying $1.8bn
dividends from HZL in April (in the process losing $844m in withholding tax and minority
payments) and factoring working capital (creditor days now 255). However, maturities
over the next three years now stand at $10.9bn compared with cash and undrawn
facilities of $10bn and cumulative FCF of $3.6bn post minorities.
Net debt likely to rise in FY17 but ratios coming down: We struggle to see how net debt
will come down in FY17 in the absence of higher commodity prices, given the $844m HZL
outflow, PLC dividend of $83m, higher capex and ~$400m working capital outflow as per
guidance. However, due to higher oil and zinc prices plus some modest volume growth
driving EBITDA up, we see net debt/EBITDA declining to 2.8x in FY17 (from 3.1x in FY16),
well within the revised covenants of 4x. That gives some scope, if required, to add a cash
top-up beyond the $117m current offer to the Cairn minorities.
Investment case needs higher prices for key commodities: Ultimately Vedanta needs
higher prices to see its equity re-rate – our NPV is negative on spot, as is the company’s
March-16 book value and SOTP (Figure 32). We think higher prices are likely for its two
principal commodities zinc and oil (captured in our forecasts). However, until the
company takes more meaningful steps to reduce debt, eliminate structural complexity
and unlock ‘latent capacity’, the stock remains too risky for us so we retain our UW rating.

BE

And here's Macquarie on the Vedanta Ltd debt rollover

BE

Which you can read about here, and which I think was widely missed yesterday: http://corporates....22EAB44_105051.pdf

11:59 am
BE

2 year extension on loan: Cairn India has extended the inter-company loan
of $1.25bn to THL Zinc Limited, a subsidiary of Vedanta Limited, by 2 years at
an interest rate of Libor +450bps for year 1 and Libor+475bn for year 2 vs. the
earlier rate of Libor+300bps. This loan is part of Vedanta’s US$11.6bn gross
debt. Vedanta has US$2.3bn repayments due in FY17 and it has arranged for
fresh term loans, some rollovers, etc. to meet the same. This extension
provides relief that no further refinancing will be required.

BE

2 year extension on loan: Cairn India has extended the inter-company loan
of $1.25bn to THL Zinc Limited, a subsidiary of Vedanta Limited, by 2 years at
an interest rate of Libor +450bps for year 1 and Libor+475bn for year 2 vs. the
earlier rate of Libor+300bps. This loan is part of Vedanta’s US$11.6bn gross
debt. Vedanta has US$2.3bn repayments due in FY17 and it has arranged for
fresh term loans, some rollovers, etc. to meet the same. This extension
provides relief that no further refinancing will be required.

PM

You doing a Brummer

12:00 pm
BE

Company’s law not applicable here: The loan has been extended by the
foreign holding company of Cairn India. As such, the company’s act is not
applicable to foreign firms and so this removes the need for a minority vote
given that it’s a related party transaction. It could pave the way for more such
loans as this holding company of Cairn is sitting on further cash of
US$700mn. In any case, we now see no pressing need for a merger with
Cairn and as such Vedanta will be able to drive a much better bargain on any
merger ratio compared to the market’s expectation of 1:1.4.

BE

Sorry. I'm 83, you know.

BE

Standalone assets set to sweat out: Iron ore, Aluminium and Power, 3 key
standalone businesses, are witnessing a strong recovery and we expect their
EBITDA contribution to increase from $350mn in FY16 to $800mn in FY18.
This improves interest coverage for Vedanta and should drive a re-rating of
the stock, in our view.
